the "live adult teacher" (the performer) is
being tested against the effectiveness of puppets,
simulated animation (still drawings), and speech¬
less animators (mimes). It is a frail premise
on which to spend close to ninety (90) thousand
dollars, or on which to tie up the creative
energy of people who could possibly make a more
substantial contribution with more effective
guidance, or on which to involve the resources of
at least two responsible research and production
outlets.
It would seem as though these people had over¬
looked the rather extensive experiences in the
uses of television in like situations. What is
distressing is the fact that funds were probably
allocated for this and similar "studies", by other
agencies. What is further unsettling is the fact
that the emphasis is unequally divided, between
understanding children's responses to educational
television stimuli (the lesser emphasis) and the
study of performer impact versus abstration
(puppets, simulated animation, mimes, etc.),
which, it seemed, accounted for the lion's share
